so as Sheila mentioned I created
trickster last year at Comcast and I'll
talk about the journey as to why I felt
like I needed to make it but what it is
in essence is basically a reverse proxy
cache and actually call it an
accelerator because it does more than
just caching that sits between your
dashboard application and as you can see
on this diagram I have a graph on an
icon but it'll actually work for any
dashboard that has a back end to
Prometheus so it sits between that
dashboard and your Prometheus database
to help accelerate queries that go
between those two systems
so here's a common problem if you ever
worked in any kind of industry where you
work with users at large in America
you're probably familiar with the shape
of this chart and I'll just show you
real quick it's up there so I can't see
it nevermind so you're probably me with

night as people go to bed the chart goes

as those people are waking up and using
the service more so this is just a basic
uses charge of some systems at Comcast
and so I was building this dashboard to
show charts like this to show failure
rates and those kind of things across
some of our platforms and realized that
I didn't like the speed of our dashboard
performance so and I'm gonna explain
kind of like what I discovered under the
hood as I started looking at things so I
started out with Griffin ax and I
noticed that every time that you
actually refresh your dashboard page the
entire data set is reloaded all the way
from end to end when really all you need
to collect for a refresh is that last
little sliver that's in purple on this
screen now because that's the only thing
on the changes that paint that thing on
the page that changes between refreshes
of your dashboard charts so what I set
out to do is find a way to make our
dashboard applications only request
those little slivers instead of the
entire data set every time the dashboard
refreshed so that's what trickster does
and I'll go into kind of how that works
out in a minute but I'll go through a
little more things here so each time not
only does do i refresh that dashboard am
i collecting the whole data set but so
as everybody else who's also looking at
that dashboard and so what I found is on
a typical graph on a dashboard each line
on the screen typically takes about 300
data points that's gonna be 240 to 320
depending upon how Griffin it decides to
do the step values so in essence every
time your dashboard refreshes you're
asking for 300 times more data than you
actually need to put that little sliver
back on the screen to refresh that
dashboard so we do that in a few ways
with trickster the first thing we do is
we have what's called the delta cache so
as you can see on this screen here in
blue imagine that's data that's already
in the trickster cache and there's
orange lines that are outlined on the
left and highlight and solid on the
right those are data points that
trickster needs to complete a user
request that doesn't have those data
points so a trickster does when you make
a request to your from your dashboard to
Prometheus is it looks at your request
and the time stamps at your requesting
data between and it determines what it
has in that data set and what it needs
and so it'll adjust the upstream queries
to Prometheus to only grab the data
points you need to fill the cache
reconstitute the data set to the user
and send that back to the user and what
that means is those queries can be
accelerated from about maybe a second
half a second to about forty times
faster than that and we'll show that in
the demo in just a minute your
dashboards really do go about 40 times
faster with trickster in the middle the
second piece of that is what we call
step down or no to normalization the
reason this is important is because if
you've ever used a graph on ax and you
have other people using Gravano
next to you and you kind of sometimes
see their charts look slightly different
from yours a couple little artifacts and
squirrely things that's just the way
Gravano works in that it looks from the
start time or the the newest time that
works backwards and so if you are 13
seconds behind on refreshing your
dashboard from somebody else you're
gonna see slightly different results on
your screen it's really hard to cache
when everybody's data points are
slightly different so what step boundary
normalization does is it actually aligns
all of the data points to very
well-known step boundaries like the top
of the minute or the top of four minutes
or six minutes depending upon how big
your graph is and those kind of things
and so as step boundary normalization
happens that allows everybody's data
points and not just your data points to
all share the same cache because
everything is normal or crap normalized
across the same boundaries that
introduces another problem though and
that problem is well what if we are in a
five minute step boundary and it's 101
you better let's go with 104 what
happens at 104 and you have four minutes
of blank space between that last data
point and the newest data point so this
the third feature called fast forward
will actually go out and
that newest data point at all times and
insert it into the data set as it
returns that back to the customer so
that in addition to just having all
those nicely normalized lines on the
boundaries you get that last data point
that's always the most recent data point
so not only your graphs are really
really fast but they're still as
up-to-date as possible
a couple use cases for trickster the
first one is what I call cardinality
creep how many people in here have ever
experienced the situation where you
don't control the label values in your
Prometheus you might have to get those
from somebody else here's an example
let's say you have a dashboard and
you're looking at the health of your

those kind of device types and device

and you have no control over when Apple

are you have no control over when Apple

two and so as those label values start
to creep out of your control that could
make your dashboards are a little slower
so the great thing about trickster is
since we're reducing that data set that

just a small amount those queries are
still really fast even when you have a
very deep amount of cardinality in your
from a theist labels secondly any
